Award.AwardTitle: Optimal Auction Design with Common Values: An Informational Robust Approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds research to develop new methods for identifying the best ways to buy and sell goods via auctions. Auction methods are widely used by governments and private firms. For example, web-based electronic reverse auctions are increasing used as a procurement method by Federal agencies. At the same time, agencies such as the Federal Communications Commission, the Department of the Interior, and the Department of the Treasury use auctions to sell everything from Treasury bills to oil and gas leases. This project will use game theory to find auction rules that will perform well in a wide range of situations. It seeks to develop rules that will work well when bidders place the same value on the auctioned good but have different information about the exact value. The project advances the basic science of auction theory, and will lead to better procedures for public procurement and better methods for generating public funds from the sale of natural resources such as timber, oil, and gas. The methodological component of the project could lead to the development of more efficient online trading platforms. The project therefore benefits the U.S. economy.

The aim of the project is to characterize revenue maximizing auctions when bidders have a common valuation for the good being sold. This research will develop new theories of optimal robust auctions that provide favorable revenue guarantees across different models of bidder beliefs and across different kinds of equilibrium behavior. Existing theories identify optimal auction designs that are highly sensitive to modeling assumptions. This project will develop auction designs that are less sensitive to model misspecification. Besides advancing the theory of optimal auctions, the project will also develop and demonstrate methods for designing mechanisms in models with rich information or potentially complex equilibrium strategies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded research on informationally robust auction design. The research was conducted by Benjamin Brooks at the University of Chicago and Songzi Du at the University of California -- San Diego. 

The primary goal of the project was to develop and apply new models of optimal auction design, specifically with regard to revenue maximization. The standard model of auction design that is widely used in economics requires as an input a specific model of the bidders' beliefs and higher-order beliefs about the value of the good being sold. In the models investigated in this project, we instead look for auction designs that perform well across all models of bidders' beliefs. The auction designs that are selected will therefore be robust to the details of bidders information. 

The project initially focused on a special case where the bidders all have the same value for the good being sold. This is a natural benchmark when the good is a natural resource or financial asset and, to a first order, the value of the good is simply the future market value of the resource or asset. The results of this investigation were published in Brooks and Du (2021a). The main finding is the discovery of a new auction format that maximizes minimum revenue, where the maximum is taken across all auctions and the minimum is taken across both bidders' common-prior higher-order beliefs and across all equilibria. We termed this a "proportional auction", since in the mechanism, each bidder's allocated share of the good and payment are proportional to their own bid, holding fixed the sum of the bids. This phase of the project also resulted in the development of new analytical tools for characterizing optimal informationally robust auctions. 

The next phase of the project generalized the techniques from Brooks and Du (2021a) to non-common value environments. The results of this stage of the project are summarized in Brooks and Du (2020). We showed that much of the mathematical structure of optimal informationally robust auctions that appears in the aforementioned common-value case also holds when the bidders' values are drawn from an arbitrary joint distribution. While the optimal auction need not be proportional, it is still the case that the maxmin auction has one-dimensional bids and the associated profit guarantee is characterized using local incentive constraints. It was further shown that this optimal guarantee can be approximated with finite mechanisms that solve a sequence of linear programming problems.

These new techniques led to the characterization of optimal informationally-robust auctions in other environments, such as when each bidder's expected value is known but the joint distribution of the values and the bidders' information are unknown. In this case, there is always an optimal auction that has a proportional allocation, and when the bidders are ex ante symmetric, proportional auctions continue to be exactly optimal. These results are reported in Brooks and Du (2021b).

The project is expected to continue with the analysis of informationally robust auctions in more general environments.

References

Brooks and Du (2020) "A Strong Minimax Theorem for Informationally Robust Auction Design," working paper, University of Chicago and University of California -- San Diego.

Brooks and Du (2021a) "Optimal Auctions with Common Values: An Informationally Robust Approach," Econometrica. 

Brooks and Du (2021b) "Maxmin Auction Design with Known Expected Values," working paper, University of Chicago and University of California -- San Diego.
